messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 65 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On Continuous Local BDD-Based Search for Hybrid SAT SolvingThe author list has been sorted alphabetically by last name; this should not be used to determine the extent of authors‚Äô contributions.

Paper Abstract: Abstract We explore the potential of continuous local search (CLS) in SAT solving by proposing a novel approach for finding a solution of a hybrid system of Boolean constraints. The algorithm is based on CLS combined with belief propagation on binary decision diagrams (BDDs). Our framework accepts all Boolean constraints that admit compact BDDs, including symmetric Boolean constraints and small-coefficient pseudo-Boolean constraints as interesting families. We propose a novel algorithm for efficiently computing the gradient needed by CLS. We study the capabilities and limitations of our versatile CLS solver, GradSAT, by applying it on many benchmark instances. The experimental results indicate that GradSAT can be a useful addition to the portfolio of existing SAT and MaxSAT solvers for solving Boolean satisfiability and optimization problems.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 65 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 65"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Boolean satisfiability: theory and engineering",
        "GRASP: A Search Algorithm For Propositional Satisfiability",
        "A Computing Procedure for Quantification Theory",
        "A Machine Program for Theorem-Proving",
        "Chaff: Engineering an efficient sat solver",
        "An Extensible SAT-Solver",
        "PicoSAT Essentials",
        "Lingeling , Plingeling , PicoSAT and PrecoSAT at SAT Race 2010",
        "Lazy Clause Exchange Policy for Parallel SAT Solvers",
        "Machine Learning for SAT Solvers",
        "A New Method for Solving Hard Satisfiability Problems",
        "Local Search Strategies for Satisfiability Testing",
        "Evidence for Invariants in Local Search",
        "Local search algorithms for sat: An empirical evaluation",
        "Scaling and probabilistic smoothing: Efficient dynamic local search for sat",
        "Choosing Probability Distributions for Stochastic Local Search and the Role of Make versus Break",
        "Ccanr: A configuration checking based local search solver for non-random satisfiability",
        "Computational experience with an interior point algorithm on the satisfiability problem",
        "Global optimization for satisfiability (sat) problem",
        "Biclique Cryptanalysis of the Full AES",
        "Graph Coloring with Cardinality Constraints on the Neighborhoods",
        "The Hardness of 3-Uniform Hypergraph Coloring",
        "CNF Encodings, Handbook of Satisfiability: Volume 185 Frontiers in Artificial Intelligence and Applications",
        "Exploiting Cardinality Encodings in Parallel Maximum Satisfiability",
        "Extending SAT Solvers to Cryptographic Problems",
        "Pueblo: A hybrid pseudo-boolean sat solver",
        "Generalizing Boolean Satisfiability II: Theory",
        "FourierSAT: A Fourier Expansion-Based Algebraic Framework for Solving Hybrid Boolean Constraints",
        "Parallel Weighted Model Counting with Tensor Networks",
        "The complexity of enumeration and reliability problems",
        "Binary decision diagrams and beyond: enabling technologies for formal verification",
        "CUDD: CU Decision Diagram Package Release 3.0.0",
        "The Breakout Method for Escaping from Local Minima",
        "A discrete lagrangian-based global-search method for solving satisfiability problems",
        "Incomplete algorithms",
        "Analysis of Boolean Functions",
        "Non-convex Optimization for Machine Learning",
        "Numerical optimization",
        "Derivative-free optimization methods",
        "A theoretical and empirical comparison of gradient approximations in derivative-free optimization",
        "A survey of non-gradient optimization methods in structural engineering",
        "Efficient spectral coefficient calculation using circuit output probabilities",
        "Symbolic techniques in satisfiability solving",
        "ADDMC: Weighted Model Counting with Algebraic Decision Diagrams",
        "Chapter 4 - belief updating by network propagation",
        "Probability propagation",
        "Representations of Discrete Functions",
        "Translating pseudo-boolean constraints into cnf",
        "Algorithm 733: Tomp‚Äìfortran modules for optimal control calculations",
        "A class of globally convergent optimization methods based on conservative convex separable approximations",
        "The NLopt nonlinear-optimization package",
        "Methods of conjugate gradients for solving linear systems",
        "Practical Methods of Optimization",
        "Dlib-ml: A machine learning toolkit",
        "Improving Walksat for Random k-Satisfiability Problem with k >> 3",
        "Open-wbo: A modular maxsat solver,",
        "Construction of an robdd for a pb-constraint in band form and related techniques for pb-solvers",
        "Divide and Conquer: Towards Faster Pseudo-Boolean Solving",
        "Core-boosted linear search for incomplete maxsat",
        "The mixing method: coordinate descent for low-rank semidefinite programming",
        "PySAT: A Python Toolkit for Prototyping with SAT Oracles",
        "Integrating Equivalency Reasoning into Davis-Putnam Procedure",
        "Combining the kùëòk-CNF and XOR Phase-Transitions",
        "Phase Transition Behavior of Cardinality and XOR Constraints",
        "Solving (weighted) partial maxsat by dynamic local search for sat"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 65 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On Continuous Local BDD-Based Search for Hybrid SAT SolvingThe author list has been sorted alphabetically by last name; this should not be used to determine the extent of authors‚Äô contributions., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
